title: Building An Open Source Linux Computing System On RISC-V

sentences.text: Abstract—As is commonly known, hardware in a computer system requires a processor to run the operating system.
The primary architectures that form the basis of most processors are CISC and RISC.
CISC includes long sub-level commands for effective memory management and simple compiler implementations to be developed.
Thus CISC has a complex set of commands; hence the name Complex Instruction Set Computer.
On the other hand, CISC has had backward compatibility since the 1970s.
Reduced Instruction Set Computer (RISC), the other popular architecture, simplifies command sets and handles access to memory with load-store commands.
Since the instruction set is simplified, the hardware runs faster.
In addition, RISC-based processors contain less chip-sets and may be designed faster.
Currently, with the prevalence of the Internet of Things (IoT), the demand for RISC architectures has increased and its usage in embedded devices has become widespread.
The ARM processor is a successful example of the RISC architecture adaptation.
However, ARM processor production has certain license term limitations and contains a few design flaws in its architecture [1].

In 2010, the RISC-V processor architecture, which was developed as an open source instruction set at Berkeley University, paves the way for open source hardware in terms of its BSD license and design professionalism.
As a result, it will be possible to produce their own processors for communities and organizations without license restrictions.
In this paper, we discuss the building blocks of the development life-cycle of an open source operating system on the RISC-V architecture.
As an operating system base, we implement MILIS Linux, an open source operating system development project.
It has an independent user space and its own package manager.
For a completely independent open source computing system, open source RISC-V hardware architecture provides the freedom that is needed.
A. RISC-V
In order to understand the RISC-V architectures that are used by current processor families, first it is essential to understand RISC.
These processors have a general set of instructions that are more homogeneous in length and execution time than CISC, which corresponds to more basic computational operations.
The implementation of the instructions is optimized and cluster command processing is used to increase the operating speed.
More register areas to minimize memory usage is included.
In order to achieve less memory and processing power, methods such as compression of the instruction set are utilized [2].
The disclosure of the Meltdown and Spectre vulnerabilities [1] shows that if we apply high security at software level, still weakness of computing resumes if we don't ensure at hardware level.
Processors are executing instructions in the computer with high-level access rights.
Some of the runtime conditions of the system are not visible, such as the Intel management engine [3].
In order to overcome this vulnerability, we have to make use of the open source synergy that Linux creates in the kernel on the hardware side.
Because the opening of ISA (Instruction Set Architecture), it can be discovered and improved by industry experts, commercial innovators and top academics.
The ability to add extensions to basic ISA makes it suitable for applications that require special configuration.
Although the processor market has been running for a long time, it has not been able to make great improvements, due to closed and license problems [4].

Although open source hardware studies have historically been conducted on Sparc [5] architectures or Power ISA [6] as open concepts, these projects have been insufficient and will not be able to create a large enough open source ecosystem.
Similarly, OpenRISC [7] is based on the open-source processor architecture OpenRISC1000.
Although Linux kernel 3.1 is supported, kernel-based improvements have slowed down over time.
Currently, though there is insufficient attention paid to these types of advances, Debian produced a port in 2014.
However, it closed the project due to copyright reasons in 2016.
But since UC-Berkeley started designing the RISC-V command set architecture, there has been new mobilization in academia and industry [8].
First of all, RISC-V is free and open source.
The usage license is licensed under the BSD license.
RISC-V primarily focuses on defining the command set architecture rather than specific implementations.
Still, there are also free open source core hardware designs [9].
RISC-V which is a nice leap for the processor sector has started to support many companies.
Technology relevant companies from many countries participated to RISC-V foundation.

Some major companies and institutes that contribute this foundation include; IIT Madras(India) [10], ETH Zurich(Swiss) [11], ASTC(Australia) [12], Barcelona Supercomputing Center(Spain) [13], ASELSAN(Turkey) [14].
By the way Western Digital also started to develop and use RISC-V architecture based processors in storage devices [15].
Unlike OpenRISC, RISC-V is aimed at a wider range of applications.
The Linux kernel's support for RISC-V is fairly new, starting with version 4.15 and 5.0 provides more extensive support, as well as RISC-V / Linux support for the kernel porting.
One of the outputs of RISC-V for hardware is to offer a more secure architecture and processor capabilities [12].
Due to the lack of speculative memory access in the RISC-V processor, there is no hardware weakness such as the Meltdown-Spectre vulnerability.
The most important advantage of RISC-V is that it is easy to apply qualified security ideas because the work is carried out as open source.
B. MILIS Linux
MILIS (Milli Isletim Sistemi in Turkish) [16] project is a Linux distribution project that started voluntarily in 2016 and implemented using LFS (Linux from Scratch) [17] techniques.
Since 2019, the project is supported by Akdeniz University BAP unit [18].
MILIS Linux differs from other GNU/Linux projects with its independent base and own package manager.
For the time being, a desktop-targeted operating system is being developed for x86-64 systems.
Target users of MILIS are, primarily government agencies, commercial organizations and private users.
It has the goal of being a free and easy to use operating system for individual and organizational use.
Unlike the other distributions, which is commonly forked from Debian, MILIS is not based on any existing Linux distribution.
It has its own package production collection and independent root file-system production.
It has open development platform for developers by providing pure Linux usage and development experience.
Secure network structure may easily be configured via a web browser.
Although the project has been initiated voluntarily, it has the ultimate goal of being an open source software ecosystem for the academic environment.
MILIS Linux project now aims to completely work on open source hardware and be one of the first in among Linux distributions.
Such open source hardware and operating system will have the benefit of being immune to world trade disputes such as the recent developments of Huawei product bans.
C. MILIS Linux and RISC-V
In order to achieve a completely open and secure system, related studies were followed and concluded that the RISC-V ISA study seem to be the most promising.
The members of the RISC-V foundation include some reputable companies including ASELSAN as a silver member.
ASELSAN and Bilkent University are collaborating to produce chips using RISC-V architecture [19].
Although R&D for chip production is ongoing, to our knowledge, we are not aware of any operating system work locally to support such architecture.
Globally, such work is also limited to few distributions.
To remedy this gap, we are developing a fork of the MILIS project to support RISC-V architecture.
In addition, it is desired to work as a separate branch for embedded devices.
It is expected that with an increasing interest in IoT and Industry 4.0, such software will likely have high interest.
Currently, Genpro from Israel [20] and Shakti [21] from India are working on new generation processors based on RISC-V architecture.
Recent interest in open processor architecture are likely to promote the open source operating systems.
The MILIS project is now planned to be one of the first open source Linux based OS targeting RISC-V.
With the RISC-V processor productions, Si-five has produced a number of development motherboards for developers [22].
Linux distributions on motherboards with these processors started to gain momentum.
Legacy distributions such as Debian have created a project group on the RISC-V and started porting as infrastructure transfer work [23].
Fedora develops a native OS by compiling packages targeting RISC-V.
It has also established a web-based compilation tracking system [24].
Apart from these, it can also produce minimal custom Linux images with Yocto [25] and Buildroot [26] Linux Kit.
Buildroot currently ported for 64-bit RISC-V architecture.
Buildroot supports RISC-V with native and original implementation.
In this paper, we will focus on increasing kernel support and reducing porting times by a proposed reference implementation based on MILIS.
We endeavored to build a Linux from Scratch from the root file system.
Also with the rapid integration of Linux distro developers, we can improve our user-space application level.
Currently, MILIS Linux is running smoothly with 64-bit systems.
Our RISC-V architecture-oriented work can be called a port in the Linux community.
Port aims to produce kernel and userspace packages available in MILIS and a hardware based 64-bit little-endian RISC-V compatible base system.
RISC-V also allows 32-bit and 128-bit ISA configurations, however the development of other variants will be considered as future work.
• 32-bit architectures, except for specific purposes;
• 32-bit ports in MILIS have never been done, it is not necessary.
• 128-bit operation is not realistic at this time.
Since MILIS is a Linux system that applies the Linux from Scratch directives, similar methods can be used to build the basis of the RISC-V architecture.
In this section, we detail the work packages that are typically included in porting.
A. System Emulation
RISC-V system emulator may be used during the development and testing of the OS without real hardware.
Low cost easy setup QEMU virtual machine [27] supports RISC-V since 2.12.
This is opposite of QEMU's full system emulation mode, which ensures emulation devices and requires you to boot an operating system natively.
We use QEMU 4.0.0 version.
B. Toolchain
Toolchain is a cross-compiler for GNU.
RISC-V requires Binutils 2.30 or above versions to build a kernel with GCC 7.1 or above.
Currently, we choose GCC 9.1 and Binutils 2.32 versions.
There are 3 common C libraries; Glibc, Uclibc and Musl.
Only Glibc has upstream RISC-V support for 64-bit only architecture.
We choose Glibc version 2.29 to build packages [28].
C. Bootloader
A bootloader is a piece of code that executes before an operating system runs.
Bootloaders usually provide several options to boot the OS kernel and also contain commands for debugging and/or modifying the kernel environment before booting.
RISC-V specific Berkley Bootloader(BBL) may be used in this project [29].
U-boot may be another alternative, but requires more work for porting to RISC-V.
BBL will support;
• Starting and response tasks to timer interrupts,
• Boot chain loading for Linux and default boot loading process,
• RISC-V processor is not equipped to handle some instructions directly in hardware so BBL handles them as well.
BBL is somewhat special in that it cannot chainload a Linux kernel like GRUB or U-Boot, but instead the BBL compile scripts links the kernel binary directly into the BBL ELF file.
Therefore BBL must always be rebuilt within kernel.
Creating a proper separation between BBL and the kernel is planned but not yet implemented.
RISC-V Linux port has been accepted into Linux tree and is slated to release as part of 4.15 since 2017.
While this is a major milestone, still much work remains related to the Linux kernel and the userspace.
Additionally, much research and many tasks remain in the following areas:
• Init and Halt Code
• Atomic and Locking Code
• Generic library routines and assembly
• ELF and module implementation
• Task implementation
• Device, timer, IRQs, and the SBI
• Paging and MMU
• User-facing API
• Build Infrastructure
For building the kernel, we used the 5.0 stable version from the kernel git repository [30] using the following compilation parameters; CROSSCOMPILE=riscv64-linuxgnu- ARCH=riscv.
And BBL will compile with -withpayload config parameter to reference compiled kernel.
E. Pre-Root File System and Package Production
We cross-compile packages from x86-64 host to riscv64 target file system.
At the conclusion of this process, we were able to achieve a bootable operating system for RISC-V hardware or an emulator.
This root filesystem, named prerootfs, will be used at package production.
After producing the necessary packages, we will re-construct the base file system of RISC-V using these packages.
F. Bootable Image
Recreation of Rootfs using MILIS enables us to distribute an initial bootable binary disk image that is completely built from MILIS packages for kernel and user space software.
With adding live system packages, we will get a live image to run a virtual board.
Fig. 1 shows the general workflow that is applied during the building of the RISC-V computing environment.
In this paper, the RISC-V processor has been compared to other architectures and its bright future was implied.
Being opensource and its community driven design through open source hardware initiative, it may be used in mission critical projects.
Especially with the advances in the Internet of Things, the use of RISC-V processor boards may likely become popular in the market with the exciting features it provides.
Because many companies have started R&D studies for RISC-V and become members of the RISC-V foundation.
In addition to hardware information, this open source hardware that we have emphasized in this paper is the necessity of developing an open source and reliable operating system.
In this case, Linux is the best candidate on the basis of this work as the kernel.

Even though port migration of different Linux distributions has already begun, we are stressing the need to create an open source and reliable user ecosystem directly on the Linux kernel by enabling the MILIS Linux project to be ported to a different architecture.
Any development and optimization in this process will add experience to our IT process.
This study will gain momentum with the open computing proposal and will gain more.
A. Physical Implementation and Optimizations
The work outline performed on the QEMU virtual machine discussed in this study will be applied on a real board based on RISC-V processor.
Compilation and testing will give more accurate results using physical hardware.
Thus, we will have a better understanding of the components that will need to be optimized.
The compilation tools that we use in the bootstrap process will offer more RISC-V support over time and will be optimized.
In addition, alternative libraries instead of Glibc, which we currently use as C libraries, will be evaluated.
Also, with the RISC-V support in the LLVM Compiler Infrastructure [31], native compile support will be increased at the level of programming languages which use LLVM as back-end compiler.
RISC-V porting will be further explored for the kernel level difficulties encountered while providing the necessary solutions.

The necessary sponsors and research project funding supports will be provided for the R&D studies and RISC-V processors with different features will be obtained and the studies will be performed on real equipment.
B. The Future: Open Hardware and Open Source Operating System
Open hardware means license-free; namely with RISC-V virtually anyone can produce potentially better evaluations and much more accurate comparisons with existing works.
There is a range of high quality, open-source RISC-V implementations to modify, rather than just based on estimating or simulations.
Also opening standard will bring about a more active development community so that when sharing patches or ideas, projects will get contributions more quickly.
As of now one aspect of the RISC-V Foundation is responding to proposals and discussing them.
The other aspect is producing proposed changes either in a future specification revision or in hardware.
On the other hand, opening the standards and having a commercially open license would certainly make the processor design and production race more fair.

Also RISC-V will bring a new synergy of open source computer architecture research areas, such as universities started to establish research groups on RISC-V, such as OpenCelerity [32] and SCARV [33].
Research is expected to be carried out on real hardware with the increase of RISC-V processor manufacturers.
As a result, Linux kernel and userspace seems the best candidate software stack for RISC-V.

summary:
Abstract—As is commonly known, hardware in a computer system requires a processor to run the operating system. The primary architectures that form the basis of most processors are CISC and RISC. CISC includes long sub-level commands for effective memory management and simple compiler implementations to be developed. Thus CISC has a complex set of commands; hence the name Complex Instruction Set Computer. On the other hand, CISC has had backward compatibility since the 1970s. Reduced Instruction Set Computer (RISC), the other popular architecture, simplifies command sets and handles access to memory with load-store commands. Since the instruction set is simplified, the hardware runs faster. In addition, RISC-based processors contain less chip-sets and may be designed faster. Currently, with the prevalence of the Internet of Things (IoT), the demand for RISC architectures has increased and its usage in embedded devices has become widespread. The ARM processor is a successful example of the RISC architecture adaptation. However, ARM processor production has certain license term limitations and contains a few design flaws in its architecture [1]. In 2010, the RISC-V processor architecture, which was developed as an open source instruction set at Berkeley University, paves the way for open source hardware in terms of its BSD license and design professionalism. As a result, it will be possible to produce their own processors for communities and organizations without license restrictions. In this paper, we discuss the building blocks of the development life-cycle of an open source operating system on the RISC-V architecture. As an operating system base, we implement MILIS Linux, an open source operating system development project. It has an independent user space and its own package manager. For a completely independent open source computing system, open source RISC-V hardware architecture provides the freedom that is needed.

RISC-V is an open-source instruction set architecture (ISA) designed to be more secure and efficient than traditional ISAs like CISC. It's free, open-source, and has gained support from many companies and institutions worldwide. The RISC-V ISA aims to provide a more secure architecture by eliminating speculative memory access, making it immune to vulnerabilities like Meltdown-Spectre. To achieve this goal, the MILIS Linux project is being developed as a fork of the original MILIS project to support RISC-V architecture.

Si-five has produced development motherboards for RISC-V processors, leading to momentum with Linux distributions like Debian and Fedora. These distros have ported their infrastructure to RISC-V, while Buildroot supports both native and original implementations on this architecture.

The MILIS Linux project aims to port a 64-bit little-endian RISC-V compatible base system, with support for 32- and 128-bit ISA configurations. The project uses QEMU virtual machine, GCC 9.1, Binutils 2.32, Glibc 2.29, and Berkley Bootloader (BBL) to build the kernel and userspace packages. RISC-V Linux port has been accepted into the Linux tree and is slated for release as part of version 4.15 since 2017.

The RISC-V processor has been compared to other architectures, highlighting its potential for use in mission-critical projects due to its open-source and community-driven design. The paper emphasizes the need for an open-source operating system, with Linux being a suitable candidate as the kernel.

A. Physical Implementation and Optimizations The work outline performed on the QEMU virtual machine discussed in this study will be applied on a real board based on RISC-V processor. Compilation and testing will give more accurate results using physical hardware. Thus, we will have a better understanding of the components that will need to be optimized. The compilation tools that we use in the bootstrap process will offer more RISC-V support over time and will be optimized. In addition, alternative libraries instead of Glibc, which we currently use as C libraries, will be evaluated. Also, with the RISC-V support in the LLVM Compiler Infrastructure [31], native compile support will be increased at the level of programming languages which use LLVM as back-end compiler. RISC-V porting will be further explored for the kernel level difficulties encountered while providing the necessary solutions. The necessary sponsors and research project funding supports will be provided for the R&D studies and RISC-V processors with different features will be obtained and the studies will be performed on real equipment.

B. The Future: Open Hardware and Open Source Operating System Open hardware means license-free; namely with RISC-V virtually anyone can produce potentially better evaluations and much more accurate comparisons with existing works. There is a range of high quality, open-source RISC-V implementations to modify, rather than just based on estimating or simulations. Also opening standard will bring about a more active development community so that when sharing patches or ideas, projects will get contributions more quickly. As of now one aspect of the RISC-V Foundation is responding to proposals and discussing them. The other aspect is producing proposed changes either in a future specification revision or in hardware. On the other hand, opening the standards and having a commercially open license would certainly make the processor design and production race more fair. Also RISC-V will bring a new synergy of open source computer architecture research areas, such as universities started to establish research groups on RISC-V, such as OpenCelerity [32] and SCARV [33]. Research is expected to be carried out on real hardware with the increase of RISC-V processor manufacturers. As a result, Linux kernel and userspace seems the best candidate software stack for RISC-V.

Predicate-requires.label: requires
Predicate-requires.description: The predicate 'requires' indicates a necessary condition or dependency between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject needs or relies on the object to function properly, operate effectively, or achieve its intended purpose.

Predicate-form_the_basis_of.label: form the basis of
Predicate-form_the_basis_of.description: To 'form the basis of' means to serve as a fundamental or underlying foundation for something. The subject provides the essential structure, principles, or concepts that underlie and support the object.

Predicate-includes.label: includes
Predicate-includes.description: The predicate 'includes' indicates that the subject contains or comprises the object as a part of itself. It suggests a relationship where the subject has something inherent, integral, or essential to it, which is described by the object.

Predicate-is_named_as.label: is named as
Predicate-is_named_as.description: The predicate 'is named as' indicates a relationship between a subject and an object where the subject has been given or assigned a specific name by which it is commonly referred to. This predicate establishes a connection between the subject, representing a concept or entity, and its corresponding label or designation.

Predicate-since.label: since
Predicate-since.description: The predicate 'since' indicates a temporal relationship between the subject and object, specifying when an event or period began. It implies that the state of being described by the subject has been true since the time indicated in the object.

Predicate-contain.label: contain
Predicate-contain.description: The predicate 'contain' indicates a relationship where the subject has or includes the object as part of its composition, structure, or essence. It suggests that the subject encompasses, holds, or possesses the object within itself.

Predicate-is_used_in.label: is used in
Predicate-is_used_in.description: The predicate 'is used in' indicates a relationship where the subject (a concept or technology) has its application domain or context specified by the object. In other words, it describes how something is employed or utilized within a particular sphere of activity.

Predicate-is_an_example_of.label: is an example of
Predicate-is_an_example_of.description: The predicate 'is an example of' indicates a relationship between two entities where one entity (the subject) represents or exemplifies another entity (the object), often in the context of categorization, classification, or typification. This connection suggests that the subject shares characteristics, properties, or features with the object, and can be used to illustrate or demonstrate the concept, idea, or phenomenon represented by the object.

Predicate-is_a_successful_example_of.label: is a successful example of
Predicate-is_a_successful_example_of.description: The predicate 'is a successful example of' establishes a connection between the subject and object by indicating that the subject represents an exemplary instance or outcome resulting from the application or implementation of the concept, idea, or principle described in the object. In other words, it highlights how well the subject embodies or exemplifies the characteristics, principles, or features specified in the object.

Predicate-has.label: has
Predicate-has.description: The predicate 'has' indicates a relationship of possession or association between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject possesses, owns, or has control over the object, which can be an attribute, characteristic, quality, limitation, or other property.

Predicate-will_be_possible_to_produce.label: will be possible to produce
Predicate-will_be_possible_to_produce.description: The predicate 'will be possible to produce' indicates that a subject has the capability or potential to create or manufacture something, possibly under certain conditions or circumstances. It implies a future possibility of production, suggesting that the subject's resources, skills, and/or technology are sufficient to bring about the creation of the object.

Predicate-produce_their_own.label: produce their own
Predicate-produce_their_own.description: To create or generate something independently, without external assistance or reliance on others. This predicate indicates that the subject has autonomy and control over the creation of the object.

Predicate-are_part_of.label: are part of
Predicate-are_part_of.description: The predicate 'are part of' indicates a relationship where the subject (building blocks) is an integral component or constituent element within the object (development life-cycle). It suggests that the building blocks are essential, inherent, or embedded within the development life-cycle, and their existence or function contributes to its overall nature.

Predicate-is_based_on.label: is based on
Predicate-is_based_on.description: The predicate 'is based on' indicates a relationship where the subject relies upon or has its foundation in the object. It suggests that the subject's existence, functionality, or principles are grounded in or derived from the characteristics, features, or properties of the object.

Predicate-is.label: is
Predicate-is.description: The predicate 'is' indicates a state of being or identity between the subject and object. It establishes a relationship where the subject is characterized by, equivalent to, or has the same properties as the object.

Predicate-is_essential_to_understand.label: is essential to understand
Predicate-is_essential_to_understand.description: Indicates that the object (RISC, etc.) requires a deep comprehension or grasp of its underlying concepts, principles, or mechanisms by the subject. This predicate highlights the importance of understanding the object for effective interaction, decision-making, or other purposes.

Predicate-use.label: use
Predicate-use.description: The predicate 'use' indicates a relationship of utilization or employment between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject makes use of, relies on, or exploits the object for some purpose or function.

Predicate-have.label: have
Predicate-have.description: The predicate 'have' indicates possession or association between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject has control over, responsibility for, or a connection to the object, which can be an abstract concept, a physical entity, or a set of instructions.

Predicate-corresponds_to.label: corresponds to
Predicate-corresponds_to.description: The predicate 'corresponds to' indicates a relationship between two concepts or entities where one concept (the subject) can be seen as an abstraction, simplification, or representation of another concept (the object). This connection suggests that there exists a mapping or equivalence between the two concepts, allowing for translation, substitution, or analogy.

Predicate-is_optimized_for.label: is optimized for
Predicate-is_optimized_for.description: The predicate 'is optimized for' indicates a relationship between the subject (a module implementation) and the object (operating speed), suggesting that the module has been designed or modified to achieve optimal performance, efficiency, or effectiveness with respect to the specified aspect. In general, this predicate connects the subject's characteristics or capabilities to its suitability or adaptability in relation to the object.

Predicate-used_to_increase.label: used to increase
Predicate-used_to_increase.description: The predicate 'used to increase' indicates a causal relationship between the subject and object, suggesting that the subject's purpose or function is to enhance or augment the object. It implies that the subject has an inherent property or characteristic that enables it to contribute positively towards achieving the desired outcome represented by the object.

Predicate-optimizes.label: optimizes
Predicate-optimizes.description: To optimize means to improve or refine something (in this case, 'instructions') by making it more efficient, effective, or well-suited for a particular purpose. The subject ('The implementation') takes an action that results in the object being optimized.

Predicate-shows_that.label: shows that
Predicate-shows_that.description: Indicates a causal relationship between the subject and object, suggesting that the subject provides evidence or proof for the existence of the object. The predicate 'shows that' implies a logical connection between the two entities.

Predicate-execute.label: execute
Predicate-execute.description: To execute means to carry out or perform a specific action or set of actions as instructed. The subject (e.g., Processors) takes the object (e.g., instructions) and follows its guidance, resulting in the execution of the intended task.

Predicate-can_be_discovered_and_improved.label: can be discovered and improved by
Predicate-can_be_discovered_and_improved.description: This predicate indicates a relationship where the subject (a concept or entity) has its underlying nature, characteristics, or potentialities that can be uncovered and refined by the object (an agent, group of agents, or process). The connection between the subject and object suggests an iterative process of exploration, analysis, and enhancement.

Predicate-have_been_conducted_on.label: have been conducted on
Predicate-have_been_conducted_on.description: The predicate 'have been conducted on' indicates a relationship where research or experiments (subject) were performed using or focused on a specific entity, method, platform, or technology (object).

Predicate-closed.label: closed
Predicate-closed.description: The predicate 'closed' indicates that the subject has reached a state of completion or finality with respect to the object. It suggests that the subject's relationship with the object has been terminated, concluded, or finalized in some way.

Predicate-defines.label: defines
Predicate-defines.description: The predicate 'defines' indicates a relationship where the subject establishes or specifies the meaning, scope, or parameters of the object. In general, it implies that the subject provides a clear and authoritative description or explanation for the object.

Predicate-is_a_nice_leap_for.label: is a nice leap for
Predicate-is_a_nice_leap_for.description: The predicate 'is a nice leap for' indicates that the subject has made significant progress or advancements in relation to the object. It suggests that the subject has taken bold and innovative steps towards achieving its goals, which have resulted in positive outcomes and recognition within the context of the object.

Predicate-participated_to.label: participated to
Predicate-participated_to.description: The predicate 'participated to' indicates that the subject entity has taken part or contributed to a specific organization, initiative, or cause represented by the object. This connection suggests an involvement or membership relationship between the subject and the object.

Predicate-started_to_develop_and_use.label: started to develop and use
Predicate-started_to_develop_and_use.description: The predicate 'started to develop and use' indicates that a subject entity began creating or implementing an object concept, technology, or process. This implies a transition from not having or using something to actively developing and utilizing it.

Predicate-developed_and_used.label: developed and used
Predicate-developed_and_used.description: The predicate 'developed and used' indicates a relationship where the subject has created or designed something (the object), which was then employed, implemented, or put into practice. This connection highlights the subject's role as an innovator or creator of the object, emphasizing their involvement in bringing it to life.

Predicate-supports.label: supports
Predicate-supports.description: Indicates that a subject provides or offers resources, capabilities, or functionality to an object. This predicate suggests a relationship of enabling or facilitating, where the subject enables or supports the existence, operation, or effectiveness of the object.

Predicate-has_no_hardware_weakness.label: has no hardware weakness
Predicate-has_no_hardware_weakness.description: This predicate indicates that a given entity (subject) does not possess any inherent or built-in vulnerabilities or flaws in its design or implementation, which could be exploited by an attacker to compromise its security. The object represents a type of weakness or vulnerability that this subject is resistant to.

Predicate-useshas.label: uses/has
Predicate-useshas.description: The predicate 'uses/has' indicates a relationship of possession or utilization between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject has control over, relies on, or makes use of something represented by the object.

Predicate-initiated_voluntarily.label: initiated voluntarily
Predicate-initiated_voluntarily.description: The predicate 'initiated voluntarily' indicates that the subject took deliberate and intentional action to start or begin something (represented by the object), without being forced, coerced, or compelled to do so.

Predicate-is_supported_by.label: is supported by
Predicate-is_supported_by.description: Indicates a relationship where the subject's existence or activity is facilitated, funded, or backed up by the object. The predicate 'is supported by' suggests that the object provides resources, authority, or validation for the subject to continue its work or operation.

Predicate-differs_from.label: differs from
Predicate-differs_from.description: The predicate 'differs from' indicates a relationship of distinction or non-identity between two entities. It suggests that there are significant differences, disparities, or distinctions between the subject and object, implying they do not share common characteristics, features, or properties.

Predicate-being_developed_for.label: being developed for
Predicate-being_developed_for.description: The predicate 'being developed for' indicates a relationship between an entity (the subject) and its intended or designed purpose, functionality, or target audience. It suggests that the subject has been created or modified to serve a specific need or requirement specified by the object.

Predicate-forked_from.label: forked from
Predicate-forked_from.description: The predicate 'forked from' indicates that the subject (a software project or system) originated as a copy of the object (another software project or system), often with modifications, extensions, or divergent development. This relationship suggests a historical connection between the two entities, where the subject is derived from and builds upon the work represented by the object.

Predicate-is_true_about.label: is true about
Predicate-is_true_about.description: The predicate 'is true about' indicates a relationship between the subject and object where the statement or description provided by the subject accurately describes or characterizes the object. In other words, it suggests that the truth value of the subject is applicable to the object.

Predicate-provides.label: provides
Predicate-provides.description: The predicate 'provides' indicates a relationship where the subject offers or furnishes something to someone or something else. It implies that the subject has access, control, or expertise over the object and makes it available for use, consideration, or consumption.

Predicate-may_be_configured_via.label: may be configured via
Predicate-may_be_configured_via.description: This predicate indicates that the subject can be modified or customized using the object as an interface. The object provides the means by which the subject's configuration or settings are altered, potentially allowing for a specific level of control or customization.

Predicate-aims_to.label: aims to
Predicate-aims_to.description: The predicate 'aims to' indicates a subject's intention or goal towards achieving something. It implies that the subject has a deliberate plan or objective, which is described by the object of the predicate. The connection between the subject and object is one of purposeful striving or endeavoring.

Predicate-work_on.label: work on
Predicate-work_on.description: To engage in an effort or activity aimed at developing, improving, maintaining, or refining something (the object), often with a sense of dedication and commitment. The subject is typically an entity that takes on this endeavor.

Predicate-started.label: started
Predicate-started.description: Indicates that a specific event or point of time marks the beginning of an activity, process, or state. The subject represents the entity that started something, and the object specifies when this starting point occurred.

Predicate-implemented_using.label: implemented using
Predicate-implemented_using.description: The predicate 'implemented using' indicates that the subject (a software or system) was developed or constructed by utilizing a specific method, framework, toolset, or technology represented by the object. This relationship highlights how the subject's design and functionality were influenced or shaped by the object.

Predicate-develops_for.label: develops for
Predicate-develops_for.description: The predicate 'develops for' indicates a relationship between a subject (a software or system) and an object (a specific platform, architecture, or type of systems), suggesting that the subject has been designed, optimized, or tailored to operate effectively on or with the specified object.

Predicate-usesrelated_to.label: uses/related to
Predicate-usesrelated_to.description: The predicate 'uses/related to' indicates a connection between the subject and object where the subject has some kind of association or affiliation with the object. This can include, but is not limited to, authorship, development, maintenance, or utilization of the object.

Predicate-developing.label: developing
Predicate-developing.description: The predicate 'developing' indicates a process of creating or improving something (the object), often through deliberate effort and planning. It suggests that the subject has taken an active role in shaping, refining, or innovating the object over time.

Predicate-include.label: include
Predicate-include.description: The predicate 'include' indicates a relationship where the subject entity encompasses or comprises the object entity. This can imply membership, containment, or integration of the object within the scope or structure defined by the subject.

Predicate-have_as_a_member.label: have as a member
Predicate-have_as_a_member.description: This predicate indicates that the subject has the object as one of its constituent parts or components. The relationship between the subject and object is one of inclusion, where the object is a part of the subject's whole.

Predicate-are_collaborating_to_produce.label: are collaborating to produce
Predicate-are_collaborating_to_produce.description: The predicate 'are collaborating to produce' indicates a joint effort or partnership between the subject and other entities (not explicitly mentioned), aimed at creating or bringing into existence something represented by the object. This collaboration implies mutual cooperation, shared goals, and a common objective.

Predicate-collaborating.label: collaborating
Predicate-collaborating.description: The predicate 'collaborating' indicates a joint effort or partnership between two entities (subject and object), where they work together to achieve a common goal, share resources, expertise, or knowledge.

Predicate-is_ongoing_for.label: is ongoing for
Predicate-is_ongoing_for.description: The predicate 'is ongoing for' indicates a relationship between an activity or process (subject) and its duration or scope (object), suggesting that the subject is currently engaged with, focused on, or dedicated to achieving something within the context of the object.

Predicate-is_limited_to.label: is limited to
Predicate-is_limited_to.description: The predicate 'is limited to' indicates a restriction or boundary on the subject with respect to the object. It suggests that the extent of the subject is confined, bounded, or circumscribed by the object, implying a sense of scope, range, or applicability.

Predicate-developing_a_fork_of.label: developing a fork of
Predicate-developing_a_fork_of.description: The predicate 'developing a fork of' indicates that the subject (an entity or group) is creating an alternative version or modification of something specified by the object, which can be a project, software, concept, etc. The verb suggests a creative process where the subject takes inspiration from the original and creates its own distinct iteration.

Predicate-support.label: support
Predicate-support.description: To support means to provide backing or endorsement for something, often implying a sense of validation, approval, or promotion. In this context, it connects the subject (the entity providing support) with the object (the thing being supported), indicating that the former is actively promoting or upholding the latter.

Predicate-desires_to_work_as_a_separate.label: desires to work as a separate
Predicate-desires_to_work_as_a_separate.description: The predicate 'desires to work as a separate' indicates that the subject has an aspiration or intention to operate independently from others, often with regards to their professional or personal endeavors. It suggests a sense of autonomy and self-sufficiency.

Predicate-work_as_a_separate_for.label: work as a separate for
Predicate-work_as_a_separate_for.description: The predicate 'work as a separate for' indicates that the subject performs a distinct function or role with respect to the object. It suggests a specific relationship between the subject and the object, where the subject takes on a unique responsibility or capacity related to the object.

Predicate-is_expected_that_with_an_incre.label: is expected that with an increasing interest in
Predicate-is_expected_that_with_an_incre.description: The predicate 'is expected that with an increasing interest in' indicates a prediction or anticipation about the subject's growing enthusiasm for the object. It suggests that as interest in the object increases, certain outcomes or developments are anticipated to occur.

Predicate-are_working_on.label: are working on
Predicate-are_working_on.description: The predicate 'are working on' indicates that the subject (a person or entity) is actively engaged in developing, creating, or refining something represented by the object. This relationship suggests a sense of effort, dedication, and progress towards achieving a goal.

Predicate-are_likely_to_promote.label: are likely to promote
Predicate-are_likely_to_promote.description: The predicate 'are likely to promote' indicates a potential causal relationship between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject has the capacity or tendency to bring about, facilitate, or contribute to the existence or growth of the object in some way.

Predicate-promote.label: promote
Predicate-promote.description: To promote means to actively support or advocate for something (the object), often with the intention of increasing its visibility, adoption, or influence. In this sense, the predicate 'promote' connects the subject and object by indicating that the subject is taking a proactive role in advancing or championing the object.

Predicate-planned_to_be.label: planned to be
Predicate-planned_to_be.description: Indicates a future intention or goal for something (subject) to become or have a certain quality or characteristic described by the object. The predicate 'planned to be' suggests that the subject has intentionally aimed to achieve or possess the state, property, or attribute specified in the object.

Predicate-targeting.label: targeting
Predicate-targeting.description: Indicates that a subject (typically an initiative or effort) aims to achieve or focus on a specific object (often a goal, technology, or platform).

Predicate-is_planned_to_be_one_of_the_fi.label: is planned to be one of the first open source Linux based OS targeting
Predicate-is_planned_to_be_one_of_the_fi.description: This predicate indicates that a subject (e.g., an operating system or software project) has been designed to be one of the initial open-source Linux-based systems targeting a specific architecture, processor type, or platform. The connection between the subject and object lies in the intention to pioneer the development of open-source Linux-based systems for this particular target.

Predicate-produced_for.label: produced for
Predicate-produced_for.description: The predicate 'produced for' indicates a relationship where something (the subject) was created or designed with a specific group of people (the object) as its intended audience, purpose, or beneficiary.

Predicate-produced.label: produced
Predicate-produced.description: The predicate 'produced' indicates a causal relationship between the subject and object, suggesting that the subject brought into existence or created something new, which can be an idea, concept, product, or outcome. The connection between the subject and object implies a sense of origin, creation, or generation.

Predicate-started_to_gain_momentum.label: started to gain momentum
Predicate-started_to_gain_momentum.description: The predicate 'started to gain momentum' indicates that a subject (e.g., an entity, concept, or movement) began to experience increasing popularity, acceptance, or influence over time, as measured by its object (e.g., a specific aspect, characteristic, or outcome).

Predicate-support_(1).label: support
Predicate-support_(1).description: The predicate 'support' indicates a relationship where the subject provides resources, functionality, or compatibility that enables the object to exist, operate, or function effectively. In general, it suggests an enabling or facilitating role of the subject towards the object.

Predicate-created_a_project_group_on.label: created a project group on
Predicate-created_a_project_group_on.description: The predicate 'created a project group on' indicates that the subject entity established or formed an organized team or collective effort focused around the object concept, which represents a platform, framework, architecture, or other type of foundation. This connection implies a sense of association, affiliation, or partnership between the subject and the object.

Predicate-develops.label: develops
Predicate-develops.description: The predicate 'develops' indicates that the subject has created or brought into existence something new, often with intentional effort and planning. It implies a process of growth, improvement, or refinement from an initial state to a more advanced one.

Predicate-has_also_established.label: has also established
Predicate-has_also_established.description: Indicates that the subject has not only taken some action or achieved something, but has also created or set up an additional entity, concept, or process. This predicate highlights a secondary outcome or consequence of the subject's actions.

Predicate-ported_for.label: ported for
Predicate-ported_for.description: The predicate 'ported for' indicates that a subject (e.g., software or system) has been adapted to support or be compatible with a specific object (e.g., architecture, platform, or standard). This adaptation enables the subject to function effectively within the constraints and requirements of the object.

Predicate-endeavored_to_build.label: endeavored to build
Predicate-endeavored_to_build.description: To attempt or make an effort to construct or establish something. The subject of the sentence has made a conscious and intentional decision to take on the task, but may not have necessarily succeeded.

Predicate-is_running_with.label: is running with
Predicate-is_running_with.description: The predicate 'is running with' indicates a relationship of compatibility or coexistence between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject is functioning alongside, utilizing, or being supported by the object, which can be an environment, platform, system, or other entity.

Predicate-is_running_smoothly_with.label: is running smoothly with
Predicate-is_running_smoothly_with.description: The predicate 'is running smoothly with' indicates a harmonious and efficient relationship between two entities. It suggests that the subject (in this case, MILIS Linux) operates effectively alongside or within the context of the object (64-bit systems). The phrase implies a sense of compatibility, synergy, or integration, highlighting how well the subject functions in conjunction with the object.

Predicate-is_running.label: is running
Predicate-is_running.description: The predicate 'is running' indicates a state of dynamic operation or activity. It connects the subject to an object that represents the context or environment where this activity is taking place, describing how the subject interacts with or affects the object.

Predicate-can_be_called_a_port_in_the.label: can be called a port in the
Predicate-can_be_called_a_port_in_the.description: This predicate indicates that something (the subject) has a specific name or designation within a particular context or group (the object). The phrase 'in the' suggests a sense of membership, belonging, or scope, implying that the named entity is recognized as such by the relevant community.

Predicate-produce.label: produce
Predicate-produce.description: The predicate 'produce' indicates a relationship where the subject creates or generates something that serves as an outcome or result. In this context, it suggests that the subject (Port) brings forth or originates the object (kernel and userspace packages), which can be considered its output or product.

Predicate-aims_to_produce.label: aims to produce
Predicate-aims_to_produce.description: The predicate 'aims to produce' indicates that the subject has a goal or intention of creating or generating something (the object), which may involve planning, designing, developing, or implementing it.

Predicate-allows.label: allows
Predicate-allows.description: The predicate 'allows' indicates that the subject permits or enables the object to exist, operate, or be used. It implies a permission or authorization for something to happen or be present.

Predicate-will_be_considered_as.label: will be considered as
Predicate-will_be_considered_as.description: This predicate indicates a conceptual equivalence or classification between two entities. It suggests that the subject (e.g., 'the development of other variants') will be regarded as having a specific characteristic, attribute, or category (i.e., the object) for analytical, theoretical, or practical purposes.

Predicate-except_for.label: except for
Predicate-except_for.description: The predicate 'except for' indicates a contrast or exclusion between the subject and object. It suggests that all instances of the subject (32-bit architectures, in this case) are generally applicable to something other than what is specified by the object (specific purposes). The phrase implies a sense of exceptionality, highlighting that there may be certain cases where the typical relationship does not hold.

Predicate-have_never_had.label: have never had
Predicate-have_never_had.description: The predicate 'have never had' indicates a lack of experience or possession with respect to the object. It suggests that the subject has not acquired, obtained, or been exposed to the object at any point in time.

Predicate-is_not_realistic_at_this_time_.label: is not realistic at this time regarding
Predicate-is_not_realistic_at_this_time_.description: This predicate indicates that a given subject (e.g., operation) cannot be implemented or achieved with respect to a specific aspect or parameter (e.g., 128-bit), due to limitations, constraints, or current technological capabilities. It suggests that the subject's goals or requirements are not feasible or practical in terms of the object's characteristics.

Predicate-applies.label: applies
Predicate-applies.description: The predicate 'applies' indicates a relationship where the subject (a person, organization, or entity) uses, implements, or adheres to the object (a concept, principle, methodology, etc.), often with the intention of benefiting from its characteristics, features, or principles.

Predicate-are.label: are
Predicate-are.description: The predicate 'are' indicates a state of being or equivalence between two entities. It connects the subject and object by stating that they share a common characteristic, property, or classification.

Predicate-is_a_cross-compiler_for.label: is a cross-compiler for
Predicate-is_a_cross-compiler_for.description: The predicate 'is a cross-compiler for' indicates that the subject (a toolchain or compiler) has the capability to compile code written in one programming language or platform, but intended for another. In other words, it can translate and generate executable code for multiple platforms or languages.

Predicate-builds_with.label: builds with
Predicate-builds_with.description: The predicate 'builds with' indicates that the subject has a specific relationship with the object, suggesting that it relies on, incorporates, or utilizes the object to achieve its purpose. In general, this predicate implies a connection between the subject and the object where the subject is dependent on the object's properties, features, or capabilities.

Predicate-choose.label: choose
Predicate-choose.description: To choose means to select or opt for one option from a set of available alternatives. The predicate 'choose' indicates that the subject has made an intentional decision in favor of the object, which represents the preferred or selected alternative.

Predicate-build.label: build
Predicate-build.description: To construct or create something from existing materials or components. The predicate 'build' indicates a process of assembly, fabrication, or creation that results in a tangible outcome.

Predicate-executes.label: executes
Predicate-executes.description: The predicate 'executes' indicates the performance or carrying out of some action by the subject. It implies the activation, running, or implementation of a process, instruction set, or program by the subject.

Predicate-boot.label: boot
Predicate-boot.description: To initiate or start a process, system, or software. This predicate indicates that the subject is responsible for launching or loading the object into operation.

Predicate-may_be_another_alternative_for.label: may be another alternative for porting to
Predicate-may_be_another_alternative_for.description: This predicate indicates that the subject (e.g., U-boot) could potentially be adapted or migrated to use an alternative platform, architecture, or technology represented by the object (e.g., RISC-V). The phrase 'may be another alternative for porting to' suggests a possibility of compatibility or feasibility in transitioning from one environment to another.

Predicate-to.label: to
Predicate-to.description: The predicate 'to' indicates a direction or purpose towards which the subject moves. It implies an intentional action or movement that aims at achieving something specified by the object.

Predicate-loads.label: loads
Predicate-loads.description: The predicate 'loads' indicates the process of bringing into operation or making available a specific entity (object), typically in a context where it was previously unavailable or dormant. It implies a transition from an inactive to an active state, often with implications for functionality, usability, or accessibility.

Predicate-is_not_equipped_to_handle_some.label: is not equipped to handle some instructions directly in hardware so
Predicate-is_not_equipped_to_handle_some.description: This predicate indicates that a subject (e.g., a computer architecture or processing unit) lacks the capability to execute certain instructions without relying on software assistance. The object refers to the specific context, framework, or system in which this limitation applies.

Predicate-links.label: links
Predicate-links.description: Establishes a connection or relationship between the subject and object, indicating that they are related in some way.

Predicate-cannot_chainload_a.label: cannot chainload a
Predicate-cannot_chainload_a.description: The predicate 'cannot chainload a' indicates that there is an inability or impossibility to load a specific entity (e.g. software, firmware, etc.) onto another entity using a chaining mechanism.

Predicate-must_always_be_rebuilt_within.label: must always be rebuilt within
Predicate-must_always_be_rebuilt_within.description: The predicate 'must always be rebuilt within' indicates a spatial or temporal constraint that governs the relationship between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject (BBL, in this case) has a inherent property or characteristic that must be contained or bounded by the object ('the kernel') at all times.

Predicate-planned_to_be_separated_from.label: planned to be separated from
Predicate-planned_to_be_separated_from.description: This predicate indicates a deliberate intention or decision to disconnect or disentangle something (the subject) from another entity (the object), often implying a sense of separation, distinction, or independence.

Predicate-has_been_accepted_into.label: has been accepted into
Predicate-has_been_accepted_into.description: The predicate 'has been accepted into' indicates a relationship of inclusion or membership between two entities. It suggests that the subject (in this case, RISC-V) has gained entry or admission to the object (the Linux tree), implying a level of acceptance and recognition.

Predicate-is_slated_to_release_as_part_o.label: is slated to release as part of
Predicate-is_slated_to_release_as_part_o.description: This predicate indicates a planned association between two entities: the subject (a specific entity or project) and the object (a larger framework, milestone, or release).
